(6/6) To learn more about the SNAP program, check out our fact sheet. https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/_cache/files/d657a411-2fd3-4570-b352-ff86ab54aa16/supplemental-nutrition-assistance-program---jec.pdf

(5/6) Work requirements instituted in 1996 make the program less effective. Research shows the restrictions do little to encourage employment and significantly reduce the # of people who use the SNAP program. This undermines SNAP‚Äôs effectiveness as an automatic stabilizer.

(4/6) SNAP is an automatic stabilizer, meaning it kicks in during a recession w/o the need for new legislation. SNAP enrollment and benefits rise when workers lose their jobs, helping low-income families sustain food spending and keeping the economy from slowing more severely. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EDUfYQzUUAAgEPr.jpg

(3/6) SNAP also promotes consumer spending & cushions the economy during recessions. Because SNAP beneficiaries typically spend all of their benefits, the money goes directly into the economy. It‚Äôs estimated that for every $1B billion the govt spends on SNAP, GDP rises by $1.54B.

(2/6) SNAP reduces food insecurity for families and has long-term effects on the health & economic stability of children. A 2016 study showed that children who gained access to SNAP benefits either in utero or in early childhood were healthier as adults.

(1/6) #OTD in '64 LBJ signed the Food Stamp Act, which was later renamed SNAP and has become America‚Äôs most effective anti-hunger program. Tens of millions get help from SNAP, with children, the elderly & people with a disability accounting for the majority of beneficiaries. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EDUfXlZUUAQ5gs2.jpg
